notes:
1. Definition

In addition to bending stresses, an internal shear force ($V$) in a beam also creates shear stresses ($\tau$). These stresses act parallel to the cross-section of the beam and are responsible for resisting the tendency of adjacent layers of the beam to slide past one another.

2. General Shear Formula

The shear stress at any point on a beam's cross-section is given by the general shear formula:

$$ \tau = \frac{VQ}{Ib} $$
  • $\tau$: Shear stress at the point of interest.
  • $V$: The internal shear force at that section of the beam.
  • $Q$: The first moment of the area *above* (or below) the point where the stress is being calculated, taken about the neutral axis. $Q = A'\bar{y}'$.
  • $I$: The moment of inertia of the entire cross-section about the neutral axis.
  • $b$: The width of the cross-section at the point of interest.

3. Shear Stress in Rectangular Beams

For a rectangular cross-section, the shear stress distribution is parabolic. It is zero at the top and bottom fibers and reaches its maximum value at the neutral axis.

$$ \tau_{max} = \frac{3}{2} \frac{V}{A} = 1.5 \tau_{avg} $$

Where $A$ is the total cross-sectional area of the rectangle.

solvedExamples.question: For a beam with a rectangular cross-section, where does the maximum transverse shear stress occur?

options.text: The stress is uniform throughout the cross-section.

solvedExamples.explanation: Unlike bending stress, which is maximum at the outer fibers, transverse shear stress in a rectangular beam is zero at the outer fibers and reaches its maximum value at the neutral axis.

solvedExamples.question: A rectangular wood beam is 4 inches wide and 10 inches deep. If it is subjected to a shear force of 3,000 lbs, what is the maximum shear stress in the beam?
solvedExamples.explanation: For a rectangular section, use the simplified formula $\tau_{max} = 1.5 (V/A)$. The area is $A = 4 \text{ in} \times 10 \text{ in} = 40$ in². $\tau_{max} = 1.5 \times (3,000 \text{ lbs} / 40 \text{ in²}) = 1.5 \times 75 \text{ psi} = 112.5$ psi.
